newsitem.title: USA: U.S. NRC proposes fine against Thermal Science.
newsitem.headline: U.S. NRC proposes fine against Thermal Science.

text.p: The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission Wednesday said it proposed a $900,000 fine against Thermal Science Inc, of St. Louis, Missouri, for misrepresenting its Thermo-Lag fire barrier products.
The NRC said it concluded that the company misrepresented the involvement level of a test laboratory, Industrial Testing Laboratories Inc (ITL), in fire barrier and other tests.
Thermal Science submitted information to the NRC during an agency investigation on Thermo-Lag products used for fire protection in nuclear power plants.

The NRC also said it found that Thermal Science indirectly misrepresented involvement of the company and of test laboratories, including ITL, in testing of Thermo-Lag products in reports and other documents that it knew contained inaccurate and/or incomplete information.
The NRC cited nine separate violations.

"Violations involving multiple instances in which a vendor deliberately provides inaccurate and/or incomplete information related to the performance and quality of its important-to-safety products constitute a very significant regulatory concern, are wholly unacceptable, and will not be tolerated," James Lieberman, director of the NRC's Office of Enforcement, said in a letter to Thermal Science.

"These violations are further aggravated because they were committed in the context of an ongoing NRC investigation into concerns about the quality and performance of Thermo-Lag products with significant implications regarding the compliance of a substantial number of nuclear power plant licensees with the Commission's regulations," Lieberman said.
Lieberman said the NRC staff decided to set the maximum statutory limit of $100,000 for each of nine violations "because of the egregious, deliberate and repeated nature of these violations."
Lieberman said supplying insufficiently-tested Thermo Lag to NRC licensees placed them in jeopardy of violating of NRC regulations, and compromised the level of plant safety.
Thermal Science has 30 days to pay the proposed fine or to protest it, the NRC said. The company may request a hearing.
